Graphical abstract The activation of methane (CH4) is a critical step in its conversion to high value products, which require the use of catalysts due to the higher stability of the C-H bond. In this study, we combined density functional theory calculations and the unit bond index-quadratic exponential potential approximation to investigate the first CH4 dehydrogenation in the TM/(CeO2)10 system, where TM represents a single transition-metal specie (Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) supported in the compact (CeO2)10 cluster. In addition, substrate size effects will be addressed by comparing our results with previous surface science studies by our group. We found a direct correlation between the magnitude of the TM adsorption energy on the CeO2 substrates (hollow and bridge sites) and the magnitude of charge transfer from the TM adatoms to the substrates, while CH4 has a weaker physisorption binding energy to the ceria cluster and the surface substrates. Molecular fragments derived from CH4 (CH3 and H) bind through chemisorption interactions to the TM and O sites, respectively. The estimated energy barrier for the cleavage of the C-H bond is lower when the reaction occurs in the cluster rather than on the surface. The molecular fragments exhibited better stabilization on cluster substrates, resulting in an exergonic dehydrogenation reaction; whereas, for surfaces, the reaction was endergonic. Among the selected TM species, Fe and Co adatoms are promising candidates for the first CH4 dehydrogenation on CeO2 substrates, which can be explained by the magnitude of the metal-support interaction and stabilization of the CH3 specie, which results in the lowest barriers among the evaluated transition metals. Keywords Methane activation Catalysis DFT Ceria Size effect Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Methane (CH4) is the most abundant chemical component of natural gas and plays an important role as a valuable energy resource due to its widespread availability [1,2]. Furthermore, it is important to note that CH4 also contributes to environmental issues, especially its influence on climate change[1,3] since CH4 has a stronger global warming potential than CO2 [4]. Therefore, converting CH4 can achieve two different objectives: ( i ) production of value-added products and ( i i ) environmental remediation. For example, there is great interest in the conversion of CH4 to methanol, formaldehyde, acetylene, olefins and others, [5–7] which can be done through several pathways for the direct CH4 conversion; however, certain challenges must be addressed to advance to the commercial stage [8,9]. On the other hand, catalytic oxidation of CH4 in low concentrations to carbon dioxide (CO2) can also help reduce global greenhouse emissions. CH4 is the least reactive molecule among alkanes, which can be explained by its strong C-H bond with a dissociation energy of 439.3 kJmol-1 [7]. The transformation of CH4 begins with its adsorption onto a particular substrate. Following the adsorption process, regardless of the subsequent conversion pathways, the CH4 activation is essential, which should lead to the breaking of the C-H bond [2,6,7]. Thus, due to the high stability of the C-H bond, the use of a catalyst is crucial for the challenging task of activating CH4. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have attracted increased interest since Yang et al. [10] reported them for the first time. SACs are isolated single atoms directly bound to the support, not necessarily uniformly distributed, which is different from single sites where each and every site is uniform, and there may be multiple metal types present with comparable coordinating environments [11]. The low coordination environment of the active center, in addition to the improved metal-support interaction (MSI) of SACs, can improve the catalytic result [10]. Anchoring of a single transition-metal atom on a reducible support can improve the stability of the single atom during the catalytic process due to charge transfer between the metal and the oxide support [12]. Cerium oxide has been used as a support or catalyst for various catalytic applications, e.g. oxidation, hydrogenation reactions, and the treatment of engine exhaust gases [13,14]. Its oxygen storage capacity, accompanied by the change in the oxidation state from delocalized f -states (Ce4+) to localized f -states (Ce3+), [13] contributes to its catalytic performance. CH4 conversion is highly explored using materials based on CeO2, including the steam and dry reforming of CH4, [15] CH4 to methanol synthesis, [16] oxidative [17] and non-oxidative coupling, [18] and others. Thus, the application of cerium oxide is extensive; for example, small cationic clusters have also been evaluated for the reaction of small hydrocarbon molecules reaction [19]. The unpaired electrons are responsible for the formation of the active site that results in the removal of CH4 hydrogen. The doped ceria substrate is also investigated for producing C2 hydrocarbons from methane. Cerium oxide and mixed support oxide with Mg and La lithium doped oxides had more basic sites and improved the production of ethylene and ethane [17]. The use of promoters to improve catalyst performance is another strategy. The Ceria oxide-supporting catalysts Ni promoted with Ga showed coke resistance and high conversion for the dry reforming of methane [20]. The strong interaction of a single metal atom with CeO2, along with its reversible oxygen storage capacity, results in a wide range of applications for SACs based on CeO2 [21]. Several ceria-based SACs have presented superior catalytic performance compared to their nanoparticulated counterparts [18,22]. In this context, CeO2 nanorods with Ni and Ru as dual single-atom sites were capable of activating CH4 in dry reforming, with high selectivity to produce H2 [23]. Theoretical calculations, based on density functional theory (DFT), have suggested that activation of CH4 is a rate determining step that presents the highest energy barrier during the process [23]. Xie and co-workers[18] reported a Pt single atom supported in ceria capable of direct conversion of CH4 into C2 products. Furthermore, the catalyst was stable and resistant to coke formation at the active site. A single-atom Pt/CeO2 catalyst was also investigated by Bajec et al., [24] for the conversion of CH4 into C2 products. The applied microkinetic model revealed that the adsorption and desorption of the reactants and products and the first dehydrogenation of methane were crucial steps. Therefore, to improve our atomistic understanding of ceria-based catalysts, we will report a theoretical investigation of the first CH4 dehydrogenation in the TM/(CeO2)10 cluster [25]. Furthermore, to address substrate size effects, our data will be compared directly with the first CH4 dehydrogenation in the TM/CeO2(111) substrate [26]. To do that, we combined DFT calculations and the unit bond index-quadratic exponential potential (UBI-QEP) approximation [27–29]. We find that the ceria cluster substrates had a lower estimated activation energy barrier for dissociation of the C-H bond than the surface substrates. Barriers are related to stabilization of the fragment CH3. In addition, dissociative chemisorption of CH4 becomes thermodynamically favored on cluster substrates. 2 Theoretical approach and computational details 2.1 Total energy calculations Spin-polarized DFT[30,31] calculations were performed employing the semilocal Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE)[32] formulation for the exchange-correlation energy functional, as implemented in the Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP), version 5.4.4 [33,34]. The PBE functional is widely used in the study of surfaces, [35] clusters, [36] chemical reactions, [25,37] and etc. In certain cases, an accurate description of specific properties with plain DFT-PBE faces difficulties and therefore requires enhancements. For example, in materials based on ceria, the nature of the Ce f -states can change from delocalized (Ce4+, CeO2) to localized (Ce3+, Ce2O3)[38] by changes in the O composition or even the adsorption of molecular species on the CeO2 surfaces [39–41]. To minimize the problems with the Ce f -states, we use the DFT + U framework, which is based on the Dudarev et al. formulation [42]. In general, it introduces an effective Hubbard parameter ( U e f f = U − J ) in selected electronic states, which can affect the localization and the energy position within the electronic spectrum; that is, it shifts the electronic states and affects hybridization. U and J control the magnitude of the Coulomb and exchange interactions for the selected chemical species and the electronic state, respectively. Here, we use an effective Hubbard parameter of 4.50 eV for the Ce f -states, which yields equivalent results as the hybrid HSE06 functional for the reduction of CeO2 towards the Ce2O3 system [38,43]. Furthermore, due to the challenge of plain DFT-PBE to describe the weak interaction between CH4 and solid surfaces, [44,45] the semi-empirical D3 van der Waals (vdW) correction [46] was used for all calculations. The Kohn–Sham (KS) equations were resolved using the all-electron projector augmented wave (PAW) method, [47,48] where the KS electronic states were expanded through plane waves. For all calculations, a cutoff energy of 488.734 eV was used, exceeding by 12.5% the maximum suggested value for the cutoff energy among the selected PAW projectors provided within the VASP implementation. Integration of the Brillouin zone was performed using only the Γ -point, since there is no dispersion of the electronic states within the Brillouin zone. We used a cubic box with sizes of 23.9 and 25.7 Å for TM/(CeO2)10 and molecules/TM/(CeO2)10 systems, respectively. It results in a minimum distance of about 15 Å between the molecular systems and their periodic images, which is required to guarantee negligible interaction between the molecular system and its periodic images [25,49]. The TM free atoms were calculated using an orthorhombic box of 18 × 19 × 20 Å3, which is crucial to avoid spherical electron densities for the free atoms and fraction occupation of the electronic states, while a cubic box of 17 Å was used for the molecules. 2.2 Atomic structure configurations The (CeO2)10 cluster was selected from a previous study that explored different neutral (CeO2) n clusters, where n = 1 , 2 , ⋯ , 15 [36]. The cluster (CeO2)10 has the highest stability out of all the clusters examined, as determined by analyzing the second relative energy differences, which compares the total energy of the cluster with n = 10 formula units with that of the clusters with n = 9 and 11. This phenomenon can be explained by the existence of the (111) plane of the CeO2 surface, which exhibits the lowest surface energy among the low Miller index CeO2 surfaces [50]. The structure of the (CeO2)10 cluster is shown in Fig. 1 , which display the two types of existing faces. The adsorption of TM (Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) was carried out considering the different faces of the cluster. Fig. 1 shows two different face groups and the nine most important adsorption sites for the initial positions of the TM adatoms. The adsorption of TM was carried out in two steps: 1. Using low-cost computational parameters for structure relaxation (energy cutoff of 380.127 eV at the Γ -point with a total energy convergence criterion of 1 × 10 − 4 eV and forces smaller than 0.25 eV Å-1); 2. In the second step, the four most stable structures for each TM/(CeO2)10 system were relaxed again with standard calculation parameters (energy cutoff of 488.734 eV at the Γ -point with a total energy convergence criterion of 1 × 10 − 5 eV and forces smaller than 0.050 eV Å-1). In the next steps, the most stable conformation for each TM was used to estimate the barrier for dissociation of the C-H methane bond. To estimate the activation energy barrier for methane on the TM/(CeO2)10 clusters using the UBI-QEP approximation, [27] we performed the following steps: 1. Adsorption of molecular species (CH4, CH3, H, CH3+H) considering adsorption sites close to TM, Fig. 2 . For these calculations, we used a plane wave cutoff energy of 488.734 eV, Brillouin zone integration using only the Γ -point, a total energy convergence criterion of 1 × 10 − 5 eV, and the equilibrium geometries are obtained once the atomic forces are smaller than 0.050 eV Å-1; 2. Due to the weak nature of CH4 adsorption and to obtain more accurate forces to perform vibrational calculations, the most stable conformation to each molecule in each substrate were relaxed again considering a force convergence criterion of 0.025 eV Å-1 with a total energy self-consistency criterion of 1 × 10 − 6 eV; 3. Vibrational calculations were performed using the finite difference approach with displacements of 0.010 Å. The same reaction path was considered as in our previous study, [26] where TM and the substrate O collaborate as a Lewis acid/base pair [6]. In this sense, adsorption of CH4 was restricted to the top site of the adatom TM. Coadsorption of CH3+H was carried out by permutations between the substrate TM and O, which led to the reaction path for the cleavage of the C-H bond. Additional details are provided in the supporting information file. 2.3 Estimation of reaction barriers by UBI-QEP method The energy barriers for the first dehydrogenation of CH4 were estimated using the UBI-QEP approximation [27,28]. The adsorption energy of the molecule and its fragments is used to estimate the barrier. Thus, to better describe the adsorption energies, the zero-point energy (ZPE) was considered. The dissociation of the first methane C-H bond is confirmed by reaction CH 4 → CH 3 + H . The activation energy barrier was estimated using the UBI-QEP approximation with both the original formulation ( E a o ), [27] and a modified parameterization approach ( E a m p ) [28]. In the original method, the estimated barrier depends on the adsorption of the target molecule, its dissociated fragments, and the energy for gas phase dissociation. The estimated barrier can be calculated using the following equations: (1) E a o = ϕ ( Δ H r + E a d s a E a d s b E a d s a + E a d s b ) where, the constant ϕ represents the interpolation parameter, which can vary between 0 and 1. E a d s a and E a d s b denote the adsorption energies of the fragments a (CH3) and b (H), respectively. Δ H r signifies the enthalpy of the surface reaction, comprising the sum of the desorption of the species a b (CH4), the dissociation of the gas-phase bond D a b of the a b specie, and the adsorption energy of molecular fragments a and b . The modified parameterization of UBI-QEP proposed by Maestri and Reuter removes the dependence on the binding energy of the molecule, which can introduce a spurious contribution [28] due to the limitations of DFT in providing an accurate description of small molecules. Additional details on the UBI-QEP approximation are given in the Supporting Information. The equation used to estimate the first dehydrogenation of methane using the Maestri and Reuter’s formulation is defined as follows: (2) E a m p = ϕ [ ( E a d s a E a d s b E a d s a + E a d s b − D a b ) 2 E a d s a E a d s b E a d s a + E a d s b + D a b ] . 3 Results and discussion To improve our understanding of single-atom catalysts supported on ceria-based substrates (clusters and surfaces), we organized the results as follows: ( i ) Investigation of the effects of TM species on the (CeO2)10 clusters and its comparison with TM species on the CeO2(111) surface; ( i i ) Cleavage of the methane C-H bond on the TM/(CeO2)10 clusters and the role of size effects are investigated by comparing the results with TM/CeO2(111) [26]. 3.1 Structural and electronic effects induced by TM-adatoms on (CeO2)10 The optimized structures of the TM/(CeO2)10 clusters are shown in Fig. 2. Adatoms Fe, Co, and Ni tend to anchor to (CeO2)10 at the hollow site, while the Cu atom binds to an oxygen bridge site. Upon interaction with the substrate (CeO2)10, the adatoms transfer electrons to the cluster, causing a reduction from Ce4+ to Ce3+ of a few Ce atoms, which is confirmed by the local magnetic moment of the Ce species. For example, the Ce3+ species have a localization f -state, which gives rise to a magnetic moment located on the Ce3+ sites. Thus, it appears that the Fe adatom transfers three electrons, Ni and Co two electrons and Cu one electron. Figueroba et al. [51] reported that Co and Cu transfer three and two electrons, respectively, to the (CeO2) 40 cluster. However, the adsorption site is related to the (100) facet, while in our case it is related to the (111) facet. As a consequence of Ce4+ reduction, the average of the Ce-O bond length changes from 2.21 (clean cluster) to 2.22, 2.24 and 2.26 Å for Cu, Co/Ni and Fe, respectively, according to the increase in the number of ions Ce3+ made by the number of electrons transferred to the cluster. This effect is commonly observed in ceria structures, as the ionic radius of Ce3+ (1.07 Å) is greater than Ce4+ (0.97 Å), [52] affecting the geometry of the cluster. To evaluate the charge transfer from each adatom to the cluster, we calculated the Bader charge for all substrates. The clean (CeO2)10 cluster demonstrates an average effective Bader charge ( Q e f f ) of + 2.29 and − 1.15 e for Ce4+ and O 2 − ions, respectively. It should be noted that the evaluated cluster takes on a tetrahedral shape with Ce ions positioned at the vertices. These ions at the vertices exhibit charges approximately 0.11 e lower than the other Ce ions. In the TM/(CeO2)10 systems, Ce4+ and O 2 − ions exhibit charges similar to those of a bare cluster. However, the Ce3+ ions demonstrate a discrepancy, with charges of 0.24 e to 0.32 e lower than Ce4+ ions. This trend aligns with lower-dimensional CeO2 substrates such as the (111)[26,39] surface facet, the bulk CeO2 ( Q e f f Ce 4 + = 2.40 e), and the bulk Ce2O3 ( Q e f f Ce 3 + = 2.04 e) [40]. Therefore, the Bader charges of TMs decrease as the group increases, showing higher charges for cations with higher oxidation states, Fig. 3 , which results in better stabilization of the adatom. 3.2 Investigation of size effects on TM-adatoms on CeO2-based substrates The effect of the adatom on CeO2 substrates of different dimensions, finite and 2D, is depicted in Fig. 3. TM adatoms donate an equal number of electrons for both substrates (cluster and surface), resulting in an equivalent quantity of Ce3+ ions for both the evaluated cluster and the surface. The higher concentration of Ce3+ extends the Ce-O bond lengths in both types of substrate [26]. The local magnetic moment for each TM adatom was very similar for both substrates. The effective Bader charges for the cluster varied by 4.0% for Ce4+ and 5.74% for Ce3+ compared to the surface. The clusters exhibit lower charges for the Ce ions due to their exposure to the vacuum region, resulting in lower coordination. Although the clusters have shown lower charges for Ce ions, they have indicated higher charges for TM adatoms, except for Cu. In general, the charges of TMs show the same behavior for both ceria substrates. Adsorption of the adatom on the (CeO2)10 cluster substrate is defined as follows. (3) E a d s TM / cluster = E t o t TM / cluster − E t o t cluster − E t o t TM where E t o t TM / cluster , E t o t cluster and E t o t TM are the total energies of the adsorbed TM on the (CeO2)10 cluster, of the clean (CeO2)10 cluster substrate, and of the free TM adatom, respectively. The adsorption energy of the adatom decreases (absolute value) from Fe to Cu, Fig. 3, due to the occupation of the anti-bonding d -states of TM. This behavior was also reported for the (CeO2) 40 cluster with a different TM adsorption site [51] and for the CeO2(111) surface, [26] both ceria substrates display the same trend. Therefore, of the evaluated TMs, Fe is the most stable for both substrates of ceria of different dimensions. This strong metal-substrate interaction is important in avoiding particle agglomeration while the single-atom site is kept dispersed. 3.3 Methane Activation on TM/(CeO2)10 Clusters The conformations evaluated to estimate the energy barrier related to the first dehydrogenation of methane for each molecular specie on TM/(CeO2)10 substrates are shown in Fig. 4 . The adsorbed CH4 is the initial state and the co-adsorbed CH3+H is the final state of the reaction. The adsorption energy, which is used to estimate the energy barrier using the UBI-QEP approximation, for each species is shown in Fig. 5 and is determined as follows: (4) E ads Mol / TM / cluster = E tot Mol / TM / cluster − E tot TM / cluster − E tot Mol (5) E ads ( CH 3 + H ) / TM / cluster = E tot ( CH 3 + H ) / TM / cluster − E tot TM / cluster − E tot CH 3 − E tot H where E t o t Mol / TM / cluster , E t o t TM / cluster , E t o t Mol are the total energies of the adsorbed specie on the TM/cluster, the TM/cluster substrate and gas-phase species (CH4, CH3, H), respectively. The cluster evaluated in the Equations 4 and 5 is TM/(CeO2)10. 3.3.1 Methane adsorption properties CH4 interacts weakly with the TM/(CeO2)10 substrates. The adsorption energy varies between -0.10 to − 0.14 eV, which is in agreement with the pure cluster and surface with adatoms [25,26,53,54]. The distance between the TM adatom and CH4 varies between 2.80 to 3.35 Å in which the smallest distances are relative to the Co and Ni clusters and the largest are Fe and Cu. CH4 average C-H bond lenght (1.10 Å) and average HCH angle (109.47 ∘ ) show no differences related to the substrate. However, the interval between the minimum and maximum angle values changes, that is, Fe and Cu show the lowest variation in the angle of the molecule, while Co and Ni show the largest variation that results in the greatest interaction and highest adsorption energy in magnitude, Fig. 5. CH4 exhibits the lower cluster distance and the higher distortion of the HCH angle on Co/(CeO2)10 substrate. 3.3.2 Adsorption of the CH3 and H fragments The adsorption of the fragments CH3 and H was defined based on the most stable conformation of CH3+H co-adsorbed species, aiming to estimate the activation energy barrier. Adsorption of the CH3 fragment does not affect the number of Ce3+ ions for the Fe, Co, and Ni adatoms. Nevertheless, on the Cu/(CeO2)10 cluster, the adsorption of CH3 results in the reduction of Ce4+ (keeping 3 d 10 shell), increasing the Ce-O average distance to 2.24 Å, the same as in the Co and Ni clusters containing the same concentration of Ce3+ ions. A comprehensive investigation explored the local moment of TM and Ce3+, along with their resulting magnetic moment and the total magnetic moment of the adsorbed system. The 3 d -shell of the Fe and Co adatoms was located with a methyl electron. In the case of Ni, the electron was located in the 4 s shell, while for the Cu system, this electron reduces a Ce4+ ion. This occurrence elucidates the behavior of the adsorption energy of CH3 among the investigated adatoms. The oxygen sites where H adsorption occurs, for each cluster, present different coordination prior to adsorption. For Fe and Cu the oxygen is 2-fold and for Co and Ni is 3-fold. For all clusters, adsorption of H reduces a Ce4+ ion, [25] which consequently increases the average bond distance between Ce-O. The magnitude of adsorption energies for fragment H is higher (absolute valor) for Fe with similar values for the Cu and Co clusters. Ni cluster shows the least adsorption energy for the hydrogen fragment. 3.3.3 Activation energy We used the UBI-QEP approximation to estimate the activation energy ( E a ) barrier for cleaving the first C-H bond in the methane molecule. The original formulation of Shustorovich [27] and the modified parameterization procedure of Maestri and Reuter [28] were considered. Details of both methods are provided in the Supporting Information. The first cleavage of the C-H bond in the methane molecule exhibits a qualitatively similar behavior for both methods on TM/(CeO2)10 clusters, although the original formulation shows lower barriers, as illustrated in Fig. 5. Among the explored adatoms, Fe and Co exhibit the lowest barriers, while Ni shows the highest, showing that the following order of activation energy can be represented: Fe ≈ Co < Cu < Ni . The adsorption energy of the CH3 species is correlated with the activation energy. A substrate that better stabilizes the CH3 fragment results in a lower barrier to break the first C-H bond. This linear correlation is observed for various surface substrates by Kumar et al [55] and also for metallic clusters through correlation analysis [56]. 3.3.4 H Co-adsorption effects The co-adsorption effects, or the adsorption energy of a molecular fragment after the other fragment had already been adsorbed, are also assessed by Fig. 5. Only the Ni/(CeO2)10 cluster shows the adsorption energy for each fragment considering the co-adsorption, stronger than the adsorption taking place individually. Thus, the Ni specie shows a lower methane activation energy barrier, when the co-adsorption of the fragments is considered. The difference in activation energy with and without co-adsorption ( Δ E a = | E a w/co − E a wo/co | ) is 0.02 (0.01), 0.08 (0.03), 0.21 (0.07), 0.42 (0.16) eV for the original parameterization and (modified parameterization) of UBI-QEP. This difference shows a consistent trend in both UBI-QEP formulations Co < Cu < Fe < Ni , indicating the susceptibility of the cluster to coadsorption effects from the least to the most affected. 3.3.5 Reaction and dissociation energies The reaction energy ( Δ E r ) and the dissociation energy ( Δ E d ) for the CH 4 → CH 3 + H reaction are depicted in Fig. 5 and computed as follows: (6) Δ E r = E tot ( CH 3 + H ) / TM / cluster − E tot CH 4 − E tot TM / cluster (7) Δ E d = E t o t ( CH 3 + H ) / TM / cluster − E t o t CH 4 / TM / cluster Here, E t o t ( CH 3 + H ) / TM / cluster , E t o t CH 4 , E t o t TM / cluster , and E t o t CH 4 / TM / cluster represent the total energies of the co-adsorbed CH3+H on the substrate, the gas phase CH4, the cluster substrate, and the CH4 adsorbed on the cluster substrate, respectively. All clusters exhibit exergonic behavior with respect to reaction and dissociation energies. The presence of a single Co adatom displays the highest magnitude of reaction and dissociation energies; this behavior also agrees with the high reactivity towards the adsorption of methane molecules and their fragments. Fe adatom is the second most reactive with a small energy difference of 0.17 eV, but it is the most stabilized TM adatom among those evaluated. 3.4 Size effect on methane activation in TM/CeO2 cluster and surface substrates The comparison of reactivity analysis between the TM/ceria surfaces and clusters is shown in Fig. 5 and the reaction path evaluated for both ceria substrates are depicted on Fig. 6 . Generally, the evaluated clusters exhibit a higher reactivity than the surfaces because of their finite size. The adsorption of the methane molecule shows a similar behavior for both substrates, except Fe/(CeO2)10, which exhibits a lower magnitude adsorption energy. Concerning the adsorption of the fragment CH3, Fe, Co, and Ni, they follow the same energetic behavior. The Cu adatom exhibits different behavior due to its distinct coordination and the reduction of another Ce4+ ion, leading to higher exergonic behavior [26]. The valence band maximum (VBM) of the CH3 fragment in relation to the vacuum level is closest in energy to the VBM of the cluster ceria, as shown in the Supporting Information Figure S3, indicating greater interaction than the surface. The adsorption of the fragment H shows the same behavior for both substrates except for the adatom Fe due to the fact that Fe/CeO2(111) surface is the only system where the reduction of a Ce4+ ion does not occur when the fragment H is adsorbed. The TM/(CeO2)10 cluster substrates present lower activation energy for the first dehydrogenation of CH4 compared to the surfaces. The barriers estimated using both UBI-QEP formulations exhibit a qualitative behavior similar to that observed as the TM period increases. However, the behavior changes considering the modified parameterization procedure for the Cu cluster due to the adsorption energy of the CH3 fragment. Substrates that present strong CH3 adsorption have a greater tendency to activate the methane C-H bond [55]. Qualitatively, the lowest estimated activation energy barrier for the cleavage of the methane C-H bond is observed for the Co adatom. Although cluster substrates in general exhibit a lower estimated activation energy barrier when co-adsorption is considered, the Ni adatom reveals the same barrier for both substrate dimensions. Reaction and dissociation energies depict an exergonic behavior for all clusters that is different from that of the surface counterpart. Co/(CeO2)10 is the most reactive substrate for the dissociation of the C-H bond of the methane molecule, which presents the highest reaction and dissociation energies in the module. 3.5 TM/CeO2 awareness of methane activation Metal-support interaction is a pivotal topic in heterogeneous catalysis, affecting performance and providing options for catalyst design. Ordinary Metal-support interaction is related to particle size and shape, charge transfer, chemical composition, etc [57]. Methane conversion occurs at high temperatures, which can lead to sintering. MSI has an impact on the resistance to sintering and the catalytic characteristics of single metal atom catalysts supported on metal-oxide surfaces [58]. In this context, strong resistance to sintering can be exhibited by single atoms anchored to supports, resulting in catalysts that are more active and persist longer [59]. O’Connor et al. [60] reported a linear correlation between the adsorption energy of adatoms on oxides and the metal adatom’s oxide formation enthalpy, suggesting that the metallic adatom interaction with surface oxygen atoms has a substantial effect on the magnitude of bonding with the oxide support. In this sense, the evaluated TM adatoms transfer electrons to the ceria substrate, showing an order of stability of Fe to Cu, regardless of the substrate size (surface and cluster). The same behavior is evident for larger ceria clusters, regardless of the adatom adsorption site [51]. Li and co-workers [61] have shown, in a combined study of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, H2 temperature-programmed reduction, and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption, the following MSI strength order: Fe / CeO 2 > Co / CeO 2 > Ni / CeO 2 . Thus, our theoretical calculations employing density functional theory are aligned with the experimental findings. In addition, it is important to mention that experimentally, ceria is known as an oxygen supplier, and vacancies are crucial for binding species due to the generation of a range of exposed catalytic sites [62]. This is also an attractive feature that stabilizes single metal atoms [21]. The reducible characteristics of ceria stabilize the Co and Ni atoms, making the system conducive to the activation of methane CH4 in dry reforming [53,54]. Liu et al. [54] have shown that Co has a stronger interaction with CeO2(111) than Cu. Thus, Cu atoms tend to sinter exhibiting a low concentration of Ce3+ ions. Cu has the least capacity to reduce Ce4+ ions and lower stability (based on the adsorption energy of the adatoms) among the evaluated TMs. Robust metal-support interactions are essential for the catalytic attributes of TM/CeO2 [54,63,64]. Our results show that reducing the substrate dimension improves the reactivity of the catalyst and the stability of the transition metal adatom. Fe presents characteristics that make it a possible option for methane activation due to its stability in the ceria and the estimated barrier for the first dehydrogenation of methane. 4 Conclusions In this work, we performed DFT + U +D3 calculations to inspect the first dehydrogenation of methane on TM/(CeO2)10 clusters, where TM = Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu adatoms. First, we evaluated the geometric, electronic, and energetic properties related to adatom anchoring. Second, we analyzed the energetic properties associated with the adsorption of CH4, CH3, H, and CH3+H co-adsorbed species. Finally, we estimated the energetic barrier for the first dehydrogenation of the methane molecule using the UBI-QEP method. The finite size of the cluster was also discussed by comparing the results obtained with those of the TM/CeO2(111) surface with the same adatoms. TM adatoms transfer electrons to the ceria substrates, reducing the Ce4+ ions and increasing the length of the Ce-O bond. The adsorption of the adatoms follows the same behavior for the cluster and surface substrates. The occupation of the antibonding d -states decreases the magnitude of the adsorption energy. The TM/(CeO2)10 clusters exhibit a higher stabilization than the TM/CeO2(111) surface for the evaluated adatoms. The TM/(CeO2)10 cluster containing Fe and Co adatoms exhibits the lowest estimated activation energy barrier for the first cleavage of the methane C-H bond. Ni/(CeO2)10 is the most affected cluster when co-adsorption is considered, resulting in the reduction of the activation energy barrier. In general, for the evaluated cases, finite systems exhibit lower activation energy barriers. This phenomenon can be attributed to the stabilization of the fragments (CH3 and H). The better stabilization is due to the reduction of Ce4+ ions. Additionally, cluster substrates can relax without generating a compressive built-in strain. Furthermore, the clusters demonstrate exergonic behavior during the first dehydrogenation of the methane molecule. The results of our study are poised to offer significant value in the creation of innovative ceria-based catalysts considering the size effect that enhances methane activation. coredata.dc:description: The activation of methane (CH4) is a critical step in its conversion to high value products, which require the use of catalysts due to the higher stability of the C-H bond. In this study, we combined density functional theory calculations and the unit bond index-quadratic exponential potential approximation to investigate the first CH4 dehydrogenation in the TM/(CeO2)10 system, where TM represents a single transition-metal specie (Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) supported in the compact (CeO2)10 cluster. In addition, substrate size effects will be addressed by comparing our results with previous surface science studies by our group. We found a direct correlation between the magnitude of the TM adsorption energy on the CeO2 substrates (hollow and bridge sites) and the magnitude of charge transfer from the TM adatoms to the substrates, while CH4 has a weaker physisorption binding energy to the ceria cluster and the surface substrates. Molecular fragments derived from CH4 (CH3 and H) bind through chemisorption interactions to the TM and O sites, respectively. The estimated energy barrier for the cleavage of the C-H bond is lower when the reaction occurs in the cluster rather than on the surface. The molecular fragments exhibited better stabilization on cluster substrates, resulting in an exergonic dehydrogenation reaction; whereas, for surfaces, the reaction was endergonic. Among the selected TM species, Fe and Co adatoms are promising candidates for the first CH4 dehydrogenation on CeO2 substrates, which can be explained by the magnitude of the metal-support interaction and stabilization of the CH3 specie, which results in the lowest barriers among the evaluated transition metals.
